question: [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Filter contradiction] Can an attacker craft contradictory filters like (sender=0x1 AND sender=0x2) that pass validation but match no transactions, wasting indexer resources on empty result processing? (Low)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [TransactionType expect() panic] Does TransactionRootFilter.matches() call expect() on TransactionType conversion that can panic on invalid transaction types, causing filter matching to crash the service? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Event matching bypass] Can EventFilter match against events in StateCheckpoint or Validator transactions despite them returning false in the match implementation, indicating filter logic inconsistency? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Multisig payload confusion] Can UserTransactionFilter incorrectly match against Multisig payloads if the entry function extraction fails silently, allowing unauthorized filter matches? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Config override attack] If max_filter_size_bytes can be overridden via environment variables or config files, can an attacker with config access disable size limits entirely by setting it to usize::MAX? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Default value vulnerability] Is the DEFAULT_MAX_TRANSACTION_FILTER_SIZE_BYTES of 10,000 bytes sufficient to prevent DoS, or can attackers craft maximally complex filters within this limit? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Debug format injection] Does the {:?} format specifier on line 14 properly sanitize error messages from new_from_proto(), or can malicious filter data inject control characters into logs? (Low)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Error message explosion] Can errors from deeply nested filter validation produce exponentially large error trace paths via FilterError.add_trace(), causing memory exhaustion when formatted? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Filter validation bypass] Is validate_state() called during new_from_proto() or only during actual matching, allowing invalid filters to be accepted by parse_transaction_filter() and fail later? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Substring search bomb] Can EventFilter.data_substring_filter contain excessively long search strings that pass size validation but cause memory exhaustion during memchr::memmem::Finder initialization? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [OnceCell race condition] Are OnceCell cached values for standardized addresses and substring finders thread-safe when filters are shared across concurrent streams, or can race conditions cause incorrect matches? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Clone safety] When BooleanTransactionFilter is cloned for use in multiple concurrent streams, are OnceCell values properly reset or can stale cached data from one stream affect another? [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Status code information leak] Does Status::invalid_argument expose internal implementation details about filter parsing failures that could aid attackers in crafting bypass filters? (Low)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Error path resource leak] If map_err() creates a Status but the calling service drops the error without processing it, are resources properly cleaned up or do filters remain partially allocated? [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [TOCTOU vulnerability] Is there a time-of-check-time-of-use gap between when encoded_len() is called in new_from_proto() and when actual parsing allocates memory, allowing race conditions with memory limits? [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Recursive size bypass] Does new_from_proto() recursively call itself for nested filters with None for max_filter_size, bypassing size limits on all nested filter levels after the first? (Critical)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Optional field confusion] Can BooleanTransactionFilter.filter being None (oneof not set) pass through parse_transaction_filter() incorrectly, matching all transactions when it should reject the filter? [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Repeated field attack] Although BooleanTransactionFilter uses oneof, can malicious clients set multiple oneof variants simultaneously in malformed protobuf causing parsing inconsistencies? [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Filter caching vulnerability] Are parsed filters cached anywhere in the data service, and if so, can an attacker poison the cache with a valid filter ID mapped to a malicious filter object? [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Zero-size filter] Can max_filter_size_bytes be set to 0, and if so, does it reject all filters or cause undefined behavior in the size comparison? (Low)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Maximum size edge case] When proto_filter.encoded_len() exactly equals max_filter_size_bytes, is the comparison inclusive (<=) or exclusive (<), and can off-by-one errors allow oversized filters? [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/filter_utils.rs] [Function: parse_transaction_filter()] [Unicode handling] Can filter strings containing Unicode characters cause encoding length mismatches between protobuf and Rust string handling, bypassing size limits? (Low)
